docs.title: Beginner Networking Roadmap Using Your Mac mini
Stage 1: Local Network Awareness (Week 1)
docs.text: Goal: Understand your local network and basic tools

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
• Install Homebrew if you haven’t already
  • Run basic commands to explore your network:
  • ipconfig getifaddr en0 – find your Mac’s IP
  • netstat -rn – view routing table
  • arp -a – see local devices
  • ping google.com
  • traceroute google.com
  • Use nmap to scan your network 
    brew install nmap
nmap -sn 192.168.1.0/24

What you’ll learn: - IP addresses, ARP, ping, DNS, routing basics

docs.title: Stage 2: Build a Local Web Server (Week 2)
docs.text: Goal: Learn about HTTP, web servers, and port forwarding

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
• Install a web server: 
    brew install nginx
sudo nginx
  • Access it at http://localhost or from other devices via your Mac mini’s IP
  • Customize nginx.conf to serve a simple HTML page
  • Forward a custom port (e.g., :8080) and access it on LAN

What you’ll learn: - HTTP basics, static hosting, port configuration, LAN access

docs.title: Stage 3: File Server and Network Sharing (Week 3)
docs.text: Goal: Serve and access files over the network

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
• Go to System Settings → General → Sharing
  • Enable File Sharing
  • Share a folder and test access from:
  • Another Mac: Finder → Go → Connect to Server
  • Windows/Linux: SMB access (\\macmini.local)
  • Try SFTP by enabling Remote Login (SSH)

What you’ll learn: - SMB, SFTP, file permissions, user management

docs.title: Stage 4: DNS and DHCP Basics with dnsmasq (Week 4)
docs.text: Goal: Simulate DNS and DHCP service

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
• Install dnsmasq: 
    brew install dnsmasq
  • Configure /usr/local/etc/dnsmasq.conf to:
  • Serve a static DNS mapping (e.g. dev.local)
  • Simulate DHCP server if desired
  • Point other devices' DNS to your Mac mini

What you’ll learn: - DNS resolution, DHCP leases, IP assignment

docs.title: Stage 5: Network Monitoring with Wireshark (Week 5)
docs.text: Goal: Inspect real traffic and understand protocols

docs.title: Tasks:
docs.text:
• Install Wireshark
  • Run a capture session (you may need to install CLI tools)
  • Filter for traffic like:
  • http
  • dns
  • tcp.port == 80

What you’ll learn: - Protocol analysis, packet inspection, headers

docs.title: Bonus Projects (Ongoing)
docs.text:
• Run Pi-hole in Docker to block ads across your network
  • Run a VPN server using WireGuard or OpenVPN in Docker
  • Use UTM or VirtualBox to simulate networks with virtual machines (pfSense, Ubuntu server)
  • Create an SSH tunnel to access your Mac mini from outside your network

docs.title: Using a Mac mini as a tool for learning networking
docs.text: Treat it like a “home server” or lab machine. Here are some practical and educational networking projects you can run on it without needing to change the OS:

docs.title: 1. Host a Local Web Server
docs.text:
• Tools: Apache, Nginx, or even Node.js
  • Purpose: Learn about HTTP, ports, DNS (local), and SSL
  • Example: Serve a small website on your LAN, configure reverse proxies, add SSL with self-signed certs

docs.title: 2. Set Up a DNS Server
docs.text:
• Tools: dnsmasq, Bind, or even Pi-hole (can be run via Docker)
  • Purpose: Learn about name resolution, DNS caching, and filtering
  • Example: Use your Mac mini as the DNS resolver for your devices

docs.title: 3. Run a DHCP Server
docs.text:
• Tool: dnsmasq can also handle DHCP
  • Purpose: Learn how IP addresses are assigned dynamically

docs.title: 4. Try Out Docker and Networking
docs.text:
• Install Docker Desktop on macOS
  • Use Cases:
  • Simulate multiple servers/containers with different services
  • Explore container networking (bridge, host, overlay)
  • Run services like databases, Nginx, VPNs, etc.
  • Practice port forwarding and service discovery

docs.title: 5. Create a File Server (SMB or FTP)
docs.text:
• Already doing SMB with File Sharing
  • Try FTP/SFTP with something like macOS’s built-in SSH or third-party FTP servers
  • Learn about user access, authentication, and service exposure

docs.title: 6. Run Wireshark
docs.text:
• Analyze local network traffic
  • Learn about protocols: TCP, UDP, ARP, ICMP, DNS, DHCP
  • Tip: Use it while browsing, streaming, or downloading to see real traffic in action

docs.title: 7. Build a Virtual Lab with UTM or VirtualBox
docs.text:
• Install virtual machines (e.g., Ubuntu Server, pfSense)
  • Create a network lab:
  • Simulate routers, firewalls, web servers
  • Isolate test environments (e.g., VLANs, subnets)

docs.title: 8. Practice SSH and Remote Access
docs.text:
• Enable SSH on Mac mini
  • Connect from another device on your LAN or remotely
  • Practice port forwarding, tunneling, and secure shell sessions

docs.title: Bonus Ideas:
docs.text:
• Run Homebrew services like:
  • ngrok (secure tunnels to localhost)
  • nmap (network scanner)
  • iperf3 (test network speed)
  • Build a small DevOps stack: Git, CI/CD runners, Prometheus/Grafana for monitoring, etc.

docs.title: Intermediate
docs.text:
Network Design * VPC Setup: Create a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to isolate and secure resources. * Subnets: Design public and private subnets within the VPC. * Security Groups and NACLs: Configure security groups and Network ACLs to control traffic flow. * VPN/Direct Connect: Set up VPN or Direct Connect for secure communication between on-premises and AWS.

Small Business Networking * Join the Pearland Chamber of Commerce (even as a virtual member) * Attend Business Networking International (BNI) Pearland chapter meetings * Contact small businesses directly with a special "first-time client" offer * Partner with businesses that need regular tech maintenance but can't afford full-time IT

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: This page explains the key configuration options available in your MkDocs site.

docs.title: The mkdocs.yml File
docs.text: The mkdocs.yml file is the central configuration file for your MkDocs project. It contains settings that control the appearance, behavior, and structure of your documentation site.

docs.title: Basic Settings
docs.text:
# Project information
site_name: Project Documentation
site_description: Documentation template built with MkDocs
site_author: Your Name
site_url: https://yourusername.github.io/your-repo-name/

# Repository
repo_name: yourusername/your-repo-name
repo_url: https://github.com/yourusername/your-repo-name

# Copyright
copyright: Copyright © 2025 Your Name

docs.title: Theme Configuration
docs.text:
This template uses the Material for MkDocs theme, which offers extensive customization options:

theme:
  name: material
  language: en
  features:
    - navigation.tabs
    - navigation.expand
    - navigation.indexes
    - search.highlight
    - search.share
    - content.code.copy
  palette:
    - scheme: default
      primary: indigo
      accent: indigo
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-7
        name: Switch to dark mode
    - scheme: slate
      primary: indigo
      accent: indigo
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-4
        name: Switch to light mode
  font:
    text: Roboto
    code: Roboto Mono
  icon:
    repo: fontawesome/brands/github
  logo: assets/images/logo.png
  favicon: assets/images/favicon.png

docs.title: Customization
docs.text: This guide covers various ways to customize your MkDocs site.

docs.title: Styling with CSS
docs.text:
You can customize the appearance of your site by adding CSS to the docs/assets/css/extra.css file:

/* Example: Change the link color */
.md-content a {
    color: #0066cc;
}

/* Example: Customize admonition blocks */
.md-typeset .admonition.custom,
.md-typeset details.custom {
    border-color: #8e44ad;
}

.md-typeset .custom > .admonition-title,
.md-typeset .custom > summary {
    background-color: rgba(142, 68, 173, 0.1);
}

.md-typeset .custom > .admonition-title::before,
.md-typeset .custom > summary::before {
    background-color: #8e44ad;
}

docs.title: Adding JavaScript Functionality
docs.text:
Add custom JavaScript to enhance your site by editing docs/assets/js/extra.js:

document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    // Example: Add a click handler to all code blocks
    const codeBlocks = document.querySelectorAll('pre code');
    codeBlocks.forEach(function(block) {
        block.addEventListener('click', function() {
            // Do something when a code block is clicked
            console.log('Code block clicked');
        });
    });
});

docs.title: Custom Admonitions
docs.text:
You can create custom admonitions using CSS and the admonition extension:

!!! custom "Custom Admonition"
    This is a custom admonition that uses our custom CSS.

First, add the CSS for your custom admonition to extra.css:

.md-typeset .admonition.custom,
.md-typeset details.custom {
    border-color: #8e44ad;
}

.md-typeset .custom > .admonition-title,
.md-typeset .custom > summary {
    background-color: rgba(142, 68, 173, 0.1);
}

.md-typeset .custom > .admonition-title::before,
.md-typeset .custom > summary::before {
    background-color: #8e44ad;
    -webkit-mask-image: var(--md-admonition-icon--custom);
    mask-image: var(--md-admonition-icon--custom);
}

docs.title: Custom Theme Overrides
docs.text:
For more extensive customization, you can override theme templates:

  1. Create a docs/overrides directory.
  2. Update your mkdocs.yml:
theme:
  name: material
  custom_dir: docs/overrides
  1. Create template overrides in the overrides directory. For example, to override the footer, create overrides/partials/footer.html:
{% import "partials/language.html" as lang with context %}

<footer class="md-footer">
  <div class="md-footer-meta md-typeset">
    <div class="md-footer-meta__inner md-grid">
      <div class="md-footer-copyright">
        {% if config.copyright %}
          <div class="md-footer-copyright__highlight">
            {{ config.copyright }}
          </div>
        {% endif %}
        Made with
        <a href="https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">
          Material for MkDocs
        </a>
        {% block extracopyright %}
          <!-- Custom copyright text -->
          <div>Custom footer content here</div>
        {% endblock %}
      </div>
      {% include "partials/social.html" %}
    </div>
  </div>
</footer>

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: This guide covers different ways to deploy your MkDocs site.

docs.title: GitHub Pages Deployment
docs.text: This template includes a GitHub Actions workflow that automatically deploys your documentation to GitHub Pages whenever you push changes to the main branch.

docs.title: Setting Up GitHub Pages
docs.text:
1. Go to your repository settings on GitHub.
  2. Navigate to "Pages" in the sidebar.
  3. Under "Build and deployment", select "GitHub Actions" as the source.

docs.title: Understanding the Workflow
docs.text:
The workflow is defined in .github/workflows/deploy.yml:

name: Deploy MkDocs Documentation

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Cache dependencies
        uses: actions/cache@v3
        with:
          path: ~/.cache/pip
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-pip-${{ hashFiles('requirements.txt') }}
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-pip-

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          python -m pip install --upgrade pip
          pip install -r requirements.txt

      - name: Deploy documentation
        run: mkdocs gh-deploy --force

This workflow: 1. Triggers on pushes to the main branch 2. Sets up a Python environment 3. Installs dependencies 4. Builds and deploys the documentation to the gh-pages branch

docs.title: Custom Domain
docs.text:
To use a custom domain with your GitHub Pages site:

  1. Add your custom domain in your repository settings under "Pages" > "Custom domain".
  2. Create a CNAME file in the docs directory with your domain:
www.yourdomain.com
  1. Update your mkdocs.yml file to include the custom domain:
site_url: https://www.yourdomain.com/

docs.title: Manual Deployment
docs.text:
You can also deploy your documentation site manually:

# Build the site
mkdocs build

# The site will be built in the 'site' directory
# You can deploy this directory to any web hosting service

docs.title: Netlify
docs.text:
1. Push your MkDocs project to GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
  2. Sign up for Netlify.
  3. Create a new site from Git and select your repository.
  4. Configure the build settings:
  5. Build command: mkdocs build
  6. Publish directory: site
  7. Click "Deploy site".

docs.title: ReadTheDocs
docs.text:
1. Create a .readthedocs.yml file in your repository:
version: 2

mkdocs:
  configuration: mkdocs.yml

python:
  version: 3.8
  install:
    - requirements: requirements.txt
  1. Sign up for ReadTheDocs.
  2. Import your repository.
  3. Configure your project settings.
  4. Trigger a build.

docs.title: AWS Amplify
docs.text:
1. Push your MkDocs project to GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
  2. Sign up for AWS Amplify.
  3. Connect your repository.
  4. Configure the build settings:
  5. Build command: pip install -r requirements.txt && mkdocs build
  6. Publish directory: site
  7. Click "Save and deploy".

docs.title: Continuous Integration
docs.text:
You can extend the GitHub Actions workflow to include additional CI/CD steps:

  • Running tests
  • Checking links
  • Validating Markdown
  • Custom build steps

Add these steps to your .github/workflows/deploy.yml file.
